duck: General topology - In mathematics, general topology or point-set topology is the branch of topology which studies properties of topological spaces and structures defined on them.
topology definition: topographic study of a particular place; '''specifically'''.

Topology (from the Greek τόπος, "place", and λόγος, "study") is the mathematical study of shapes and spaces.

'Topology' (from the Greek τόπος, "place", and λόγος, "study") is the
mathematical study of shapes and spaces. A major area of mathematics concerned
with the most basic properties of space, such as connectedness, continuity and
boundary. It is the study of properties that are preserved under continuous
deformations including stretching and bending, but not tearing or gluing. The
exact mathematical definition is given below. Topology developed as a field of
study out of geometry and set theory, through analysis of such concepts as
space, dimension, and transformation.

Ideas that are now classified as topological were expressed as early as 1736.
Toward the end of the 19th century, a distinct discipline developed, referred to
in Latin as the geometria situs ("geometry of place") or analysis situs (Greek-
Latin for "picking apart of place"). This later acquired the name topology<!--
Specify -->. By the middle of the 20th century, topology had become an important
area of study within mathematics.

Topology has many subfields. *'[[General topology|Point-set topology]]'
establishes the foundational aspects of topology and investigates concepts
inherent to topological spaces (examples include compactness and connectedness).
*'[[Algebraic topology]]' tries to measure degrees of connectivity using
algebraic constructs such as homology and homotopy groups. *'[[Geometric
topology]]' primarily studies manifolds and their embeddings (placements) in
other manifolds. A particularly active area is '[[low dimensional topology]]',
which studies manifolds of four or fewer dimensions. This includes '[[knot
theory]]', the study of mathematical knots.

, the simplest non-trivial knot]]

See also: topology glossary for definitions of some of the terms used in
topology, and topological space for a more technical treatment of the subject.
